1105293353544024064.text: Is it possible to legislate away this problem, if you see it as one? We can mandate data provenance tracking and authorization control, but bad actors will always amass data secretly. We should work to protect privacy as a first principle, but it isn't sufficient.

1105292233740292096.text: We all have internal models of ourselves that we run on occasion mentally... but how many data-rich simulations do you have based on your own, personal data? Are any as good as those being used to anticipate and influence you?

1105291097784373250.text: Let's talk simulacra. Many, many businesses (and other entities) have data-rich models of you. They simulate you in order to predict your behavior, to predict it and to determine how to influence it. You enrich these simulacra with your publicly shared data.https://twitter.com/FrankPasquale/status/1105217962439516160 …

997172346254512128.text: We need to better understand our situation as we make more complex decisions with systems that provide unexplainable answers.

997172257129730048.text: I still think promoting mastery of our inherent intellect is more important pursuit than liberating intelligence from humanity... especially as A.I. approaches autonomy.

997171100344832001.text: I recall as a kid being unimpressed by our pursuit of A.I. because we CLEARLY hadn't even mastered our "natural" intelligence.

997150200627068933.text: Biases are useful. But like all strategies, if they get misapplied, they lead to flawed perspectives and misunderstanding.

997149857071665153.text: The mechanisms of perception are a great introduction to the utility and economics of bias. We cannot process all the information available to us, so we need to make certain useful concessions, using filters to focus on what's most significant to our decision making.

997128536875065344.text: I saw someone say that anyone who hears Yanny must be crazy. That kind of inability to understand how another person might differ in their opinion about the state of the "real world" is a significant problem when it comes to more important matters like policy.

997128007755157505.text:
I've always loved illusions and perceptual misdirection like 
Trompe-l'œil, and so my Sensation & Perception class at @UConn was really interesting for pulling back the curtain on the mechanisms at work.

997127440664231940.text: The illusion that what we perceive is "the real world" is blown away, and differences in people's perspective make more sense. I can't hear "Yanny" likely because of my hearing not catching higher frequencies. Thanks, @toadsplace, for all those loud concerts!

997126989281558529.text: One of the most eye opening classes I took in Psychology was Sensation & Perception, where you learn about how the body processes information coming in through our senses.

997126548099608576.text:
Laurel or Yanny?
It isn't a petty topic, despite all the other stuff going on. It isn't magic either, though it is really neat to see the differences in perception normally hidden from us, but ever present in our society.
